fields.description:
Currently, when you create an issue within an Epic, you can choose among all issue types in the project. The only way to limit this is to remove the issue type altogether from the project.

The suggestion is to make it possible for the admin to allow only certain issue types link in the epic.
fields.summary: Allow only certain issue types in Epic link

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
Extended project admins under the Screen configuration have the ability to See, Add, and Remove hidden fields from a screen, and are unable to configure the field to be visible and are also given no indication that the filed is hidden Due to the [limitations of Extended project admins | https://confluence.atlassian.com/adminjiraserver/managing-project-permissions-938847145.html#Managingprojectpermissions-Extendedprojectpermissions], so once a hidden field is added to a screen it will not show up on that screen, causing counter intuitive behavior 
 
h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a hidden field
# log in as a user with Extended project admin
# go to Project Settings >> Screens >> Edit a screen
# select the dropdown to Add a field to the screen

h3. Expected Results
Either the Hidden field is not listed as the Extended Admin cannot configure this field OR flagged as a hidden field to indicate that it will not be visible once added to the screen

h3. Actual Results
the Hidden Field appears as if it were any other field, and can be added or removed from the screen

h3.Note:
This also allows a Extended project administrator to remove Fields from a screen that were configured to not be visible by the global admin and could break intended behavior from add-ons relying on the field being present such as post functions, conditions or validators that rely on that field to either update the value or validate a value is present.

h3. Workaround
The only indication that this field is hidden is that once added to the screen configuration it will not display on the actual screen, you must have a Global Admin log in to either show the field or make changes to the configurations
fields.summary: Extended project administration can see add and remove hidden fields on screen configurations

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

Jira allows users to specify the delimiter of the CSV file during the CSV import. However, when using a CSV import configuration file which has a delimiter other than comma ','; Jira fails to recognize it. 
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create a CSV Import Configuration file or amend an existing one to have a delimiter other than comma
 # Go to *Administration > System > External System Import* and select CSV
 # Select a CSV file and the configuration file above for the import
 # Begin the import

h3. Expected Results

Jira will recognize the delimiter specified in the configuration file (i.e. under config.delimiter field in the configuration JSON file)  
h3. Actual Results

Jira does not recognize the delimiter from the file. It always gives precedence to the comma ',' delimiter specified by default in the UI.
h3. Workaround

Always specify the delimiter at the UI.
fields.summary: Specifying a delimiter other than comma in the CSV import Configuration File does not work

h3. Summary

System backup exported on v8.0.1 complains an error on Jira Cloud's import process.
h3. Environment
 * Jira Server 8.0.1#800009-sha1:f5186e157f3e26c0180673ce49d51cb56d8f7579

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create a sample project on Jira Server
 # Go to [http://EXAMPLE.COM/secure/admin/XmlBackup!default.jspa|http://example.com/secure/admin/XmlBackup!default.jspa] and export backup
 # Go to [https://EXAMPLE.atlassian.net/secure/admin/CloudImport!start.jspa|https://example.atlassian.net/secure/admin/CloudImport!start.jspa] and try import at "Restore system"

h3. Expected Results

System backup on Jira Server v8.x can import to Jira Cloud.
h3. Actual Results

The below error is shown in the application UI on Jira Cloud:
{quote}There was a problem configuring the database for import. Please contact Atlassian support. org.postgresql.util.PSQLException: ERROR: column "pkey" contains null values
{quote}
After the import error, the application shows the error below and all the functionality become unavailable except trying import again:
{quote}Jira is locked for import but no import could be found. This is likely to be a temporary issue and should clear up within one minute. If you continue to see this error, please contact support.
{quote}
!Screenshot 2019-02-21 20.07.53.png|thumbnail! !Screenshot 2019-02-21 20.16.55.png|thumbnail!
h3. Notes

Reindex and data integrity checker don't solve the problem.
h3. Workaround

None.
Consider adding yourself as a watcher to be kept informed as to the state of the bug moving forward. With that way, if our development team updates the ticket, you'll be notified via email.
fields.summary: System backup of Jira Server v8.0.1 is not valid for Jira Cloud's import process

fields.description:
h3. Summary
Repeated calls to {{IndexManager.isIndexConsistent()}} while a foreground reindex is running may lead to corrupted index.

Note, that in Jira 7.x the API method that was responsible for determination of whether index is available, {{IndexManager.isIndexAvailable()}}, is defective. See JRASERVER-68900.

This problem was reported and reproduced on Jira 7.6, at the same time we couldn't reproduce it on Jira EAP 8. That being said, Jira 8 and corresponding Jira 7.x versions contain the proper fix.

h3. Workaround
Currently there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available.
fields.summary: Calling IndexManager.isIndexConsistent() while a foreground reindex is running may lead to corrupted index

fields.description:
h3. Summary
In Jira API, calling {{IndexManager.isIndexAvailable()}} returns {{true}} while the node runs foreground indexing. The intended function of the API method is as per the documentation:
{quote}Whether this index is available. The index is not available if the index is being rebuilt or recovered. In a clustered environment this reflects only the state on the local node.
{quote}

h3. Expected result

This call returns {{false}} if index is during index recovery or foreground index is being rebuilt on the local node. This call returns {{true}} if index is healthy, or background indexing is underway.
h3. Actual result

This call returns {{false}} if index is during index recovery. This call returns {{true}} if index is healthy, foreground or background is underway.

h3. Note
* Although fix for this problem will be available in future 7.6 and 7.13 versions, vendors building plugins to be compatible across the entire range of 7.x versions are advised not to lean on this method.
* This problem does not affect Jira 8.
fields.summary: Checking IndexManager.isIndexAvailable() returns true while foreground reindex is in progress

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

Some shortcut keys don't work correctly on editor with *Visual* mode.

h3. Environment

Tested with the following browsers
- Chrome : Version 72.0.3626.81 (Official Build) (64-bit)
- Firefox : 65.0 (64 bit)

h3. Steps to Reproduce
Please just pressing the short cut keys listed below in the editor.

h3. Expected Results

The following short cut keys work correctly.

- Command+Shift+S or Ctrl+K : Strikethrough
- Command+K or Ctrl+K : Link
- Command+B or Ctrl+B : Bold	
- Command+I or Ctrl+I : Italic
- Command+U or Ctrl+U : Underline
- Command+Shift+B or Ctrl+Shift+B : Bullet list
- Command+Shift+N or Ctrl+Shift+N : Numbered list

h3. Actual Results

Some of the shortcuts are not working correctly with Visual mode.

||Shortcut||What it does?||Works for Visual mode?||
| Ctrl+Shift+S  
  command+shift+S  |Strikethrough|(x)|
| Ctrl+K  
  Command+K  |Link|(x)|
| Ctrl+B  
  Command+B|Bold|(/)|
| Ctrl+I  
  Command+I|Italic|(/)|
| Ctrl+U  
  Command+U  |Underline|(/)|
| Ctrl+Shift+B  
  Command+Shift+B|Bullet list|(x)|
| Ctrl+Shift+N  
  Command+Shift+N|Numbered list|(x)|

h3. Workaround

Please change the editor mode to Text mode when you use the shortcuts.
fields.summary: Some shortcut keys don't work correctly on editor with Visual mode

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
At the moment, there is a difference between the Quickstart template in the Official AWS Template guide and Atlassian's own Bitbucket Repository.

For the Quickstart from the AWS side we can refer to the link below:
- https://aws-quickstart.s3.amazonaws.com/quickstart-atlassian-jira/doc/jira-software-data-center-on-the-aws-cloud.pdf

While for Atlassian:
- https://confluence.atlassian.com/adminjiraserver/configuring-jira-data-center-on-aws-938846968.html

Highlighting the part regarding SSL:
- Amazon Template = SSL Certificate Name
- Atlassian = SSL Certificate ARN

Then, using the template from the Official Amazon Template, it would not have the option to set the SSL Certificate ARN. *But*, the option is available when using the template from the Bitbucket Template:
- https://bitbucket.org/atlassian/atlassian-aws-deployment/src/master/quickstarts/
(i) quickstart-jira-master.template.yaml

h3. Suggested Solution
To have the template updated on the Official Amazon Page or have more information about the two locations of the template itself
fields.summary: Amazon AWS JIRA Data Center Template Outdated

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
The broken image was not showing a tooltip or the broken attachment name unless we edit the comment/description to view it via text editor.

h3. Environment
JIRA 7.13.1, JIRA 8.0

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Upload an image attachment to one of the issue ticket
# Include the attachment image in the description
# Try to break the image by deleting it from *JIRA Home Directory\data\attachments*
# Refresh the issue ticket and you should see a broken image as shown below:-


h3. Expected Results
The broken image should show tooltip or a URL to the broken image.
 !link.png|thumbnail! 

h3. Actual Results
JIRA showing only a broken image without tooltip
 !JIRA8.0.png|thumbnail! 

h3. Workaround
Right click on the broken icon/image, open up inspect element and it should show in the source
fields.summary: Broken image was not showing tooltip or the broken attachment URL

fields.description:
Currently if you type multiple words into a Quick Search Box, the JQL generated is _text ~ "foo bar"._  I would like a mechanism whereby if I type multiple words into a Quick Search Box, the JQL generated is _text ~ "foo" and text ~ "bar"._

This would allow the results to find the cases where one of the words is in summary, and the other word is in description or comment.  At the moment, a result is returned if both words are in summary, or both words are in description or both words are in comment.

You can think of this as equivalent to a google search that will return all the text on the individual case page.  At the moment "foo bar" won't find case where foo is in summary and bar is in comment.

Whilst I can type the expanded JQL in Basic Search, that gets painful when you start having 4 or more terms. 

For more detail, see this question https://community.atlassian.com/t5/Jira-questions/Multiple-Words-in-Quick-Search-box/qaq-p/997365
fields.summary: Alternate JQL Creation for Multiple Words in Quick Search Box

fields.description:
*Background:*

Issue history shows changes that occur, along with the date/time and the user making the change.

At times it can be difficult to determine the exact source of the change (method used to make the change)

For example an issue can be transitioned in many ways:
 * Transition button on issue
 * Dragging issue on board
 * JIRA Service Desk automation causing transition
 * Third party plugin performing transition
 * Rest API

*Requested Change:*

As an admin I would like to identify the source of a change I see in an issue's history.
* This would be useful when a change occurs and the user associated with that change is unsure of how it was performed (or claims they did not perform the change).

Example of how this could work:
 * Ability to enable debug or trace logging for issue history (changeitem) 
 * Log a stacktrace when issue history is being updated. This stacktrace could be reviewed to determine the source of the change.
 ** An improvement would be identify the lines that the admin needs, and only log those lines from the stracktrace
 ** Additional improvement ideas:
 *** Make this logging show in the UI
 *** Capture this level of detail by default (instead of having to enable debug logging)
fields.summary: Identify the source of a change in an issue's history

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Currently, when Jira Datacente node is shutdown while running FullReindex task (see related JRASERVER-47045, JRASERVER-66204), there is no way to remove this task from the cluster. All other nodes still think the task is running even the node is down, so this prevents corresponding operations to be done. 

h3. Suggested Solution
Add the start-up check which removes the stale indexing job. For a node which was shutdown ungracefully and then started again, it will clean up its own stale ForegroundReindex task.
 
h3. Implemented Solution
* During the start-up, the node will find its own stale re-index task and remove it. 
* Jira is identifying reindex task by the _node-id_ - to make sure it can be cleaned, please keep the same _node-id_.
 * If for some reason you cannot start the same node again (e.g. AWS instance got removed), we provide another way to remove the task from a cluster without a need to starting node again, see: JRASERVER-68616

h3. Workaround 
None
fields.summary: Remove the stale indexing Job associated with current node on startup

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

When a quick filter is created with an Ampersand, (For example, Jira & Friends). It is shown as "&Amp" in the Quick Filter Option in Cumulative Flow Diagram.

 
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Head to a Board. Click on *Board > Configure* *> Quick Filters*
 # Create a Quick Filter called 'GHS & Friends'.
 # Head to *Reports*.
 # Click on *Cumulative Flow Diagram*. Then, click on *Refine report*. 

h3. Expected Results

The ampersand is rendered correctly.
h3. Actual Results

The ampersand is not rendered correctly.

 
h3. Workaround

Currently there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available
fields.summary: Quick filter in Cumulative Flow Diagram does not render Ampersand correctly

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

Ampersand does not render correctly in the 'Components' field when the Jira user sets their Email Type to 'Text' in their user profile.

 
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Login as userA.
 # Go to User Profile. Click on the pencil icon to edit your *Preferences*.
 # Head to the Email Type option, choose Text. Click *Update*.
 # Head to a project where userA receives notifications for, edit the component field to include 'A&W'.
 # Observe the mail notification received by user.

h3. Expected Results

Ampersand will be rendered correctly in mail.
h3. Actual Results

Ampersand is not rendered correctly in mail.
h3. Workaround

The current workaround is to set the Email Type option to 'HTML' in user profile.
fields.summary: Ampersand does not render correctly when the Jira user sets their Email Type to 'Text' in their user profile.

fields.description:
h3. Summary

Some of configuration of Jira is stored in Jira installation directory. In order to change Jira's configuration it is required to modify existing configuration files.

Because those files can change with every Jira release, after upgrade admin should reapply every change in those configuration separately. This is complicated process and it's common practice to just replace the new configuration with the one copied from old Jira's installation.

Splitting the user configuration out of existing configuration files would simplify the upgrade experience and make it less possible for Jira to be incorrectly configured after upgrade.
fields.summary: Separate user defined Tomcat/JVM/GC/Logging configuration from default ones specified in Jira

fields.description:
h3. Summary
As per [JRASERVER-61246|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-61246], a user can create a link from an issue of a project he has viewing and linking permissions to another issue in a project he *does not* have viewing and linking permissions. Then, he won't be able to delete that link he created himself because he does not have permission to view the other ticket.

The issue link appear under a *Non-Authorized Links* section, and the issue key is visible but it's title says _You are not authorized to view this issue_. The user cannot delete the link he created himself.

h3. Expected behaviour
As per [JRASERVER-61246|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-61246], the user either should not be able to create the link, or at least be able to delete it after creating it.

h3. Current behaviour
User cannot delete the link himself. It needs someone with permissions on both projects to delete it.

h3. Workaround
The Jira Administrator should have rights to delete the link if needed.
fields.summary: User cannot delete an Issue Link he created to an issue from a project he cannot view

fields.description: Dinesh wants access php repository - john-jacobs for production deployment
fields.summary: Need access php repository - john-jacobs for production deployment

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
JIRA Mail Queue sends notification in batches. When multiple events are created with a small timestamp difference, the notification sent out will be sent out in bulk without following the timestamp, hence making it possible to receive email notifications in a later timestamp before the email notifications in the earlier timestamp.

h3. Suggested Solution
Make JIRA Mail Queue to send out notifications in batches while still following the timestamp sequence accordingly.

h3. Workaround 
None
fields.summary: Email notification should be following event order

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

When Jira is connected to GitHub and "Automatically sync all repositories" option is enabled, Jira create webhooks for existing repositories.

However, when new repositories are added to Github, Jira does not automatically create webhooks for the new repositories.


h3. Suggested Solution

Add option to Jira/GitHub integration to allow (re-)creation of webhooks, including, when new repositories are auto-discovered.


h3. Workaround 

Follow workaround in [Slow Appearing Commits from BitBucket or GitHub in JIRA|https://confluence.atlassian.com/jirakb/slow-appearing-commits-from-bitbucket-or-github-in-jira-779160823.html] to manually create webhook for the newly added repositories.
fields.summary: Add GitHub webhooks during autodiscovery

fields.description:
h3. Summary
It's not possible to edit the description field in the issue if the text contains a panel with "bgColor" using the name of the color instead of the hexadecimal representation. This only happens if you edit the issue in the "Visual" mode, on "Text" mode it works fine.

h3. Steps to reproduce
# Create an issue.
# Add a panel in the description with the bgColor parameter like so:{noformat}
{panel:title=My title|titleBGColor=white}
Some text with a title
{panel}
{noformat}
# Save the description.
# Click on the description to edit again.
# Select visual mode.
# Change the description(without removing the panel or the bgColor).
# Save the edition.

h3. Expected behavior
The description is saved with the changes you've made.

h3. Actual behavior
The description doesn't change.

h3. Workaround
* Change the color name to its [hexadecimal representation|https://www.w3schools.com/colors/colors_picker.asp].
* Edit the comment using the text mode.

h3. Note
If you look in the payload of the "/secure/AjaxIssueAction.jspa?decorator=none" POST call you can see that the description is sent without the changes made.
fields.summary: Not able to edit description when using panel with bgColor, e.g. bgColor=white

fields.description:
h3. Description
On instances with a lot of issues that, when searching for a filter, it might take a few seconds to load it all and if the user accidentally hits a shortcut like the letter *a* on his keyboard, which opens the {{Assign Issue to User}} popup, the user might become the assignee of an issue of the previous or current filter being searched by accident.

h3. Suggestion
Prevent shortcuts of being executed when loading filters.
fields.summary: Prevent the usage of shortcuts when executing a filter search

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
When a customer has a large number items listed in the configuration page the page takes > 60 seconds to load. This impacts configuration page such as:
* Workflow (<baseURL>/secure/admin/workflows/ListWorkflows.jspa)
* Custom Fields (<baseURL>/secure/admin/ViewCustomFields.jspa/)
* etc

For enterprise customer, it's common to have more than 1000 of fields, workflows, screens. 
 
h3. Suggested Solution
If we could add pagination, we could limit the number of items to be displayed in one page so it wouldn't time out and it will load faster. This is addressing all configuration page in JIRA (screen, workflow, fields).

h3. Workaround 
There's no workaround at the moment
fields.summary: Having pagination option for configuration page

fields.description:
*Problem Definition*
When adding an attachment via a screen that has both an attachment and comment field, the attachment is not automatically added as a comment. This is a little counter intuitive as people adding the attachment may expect it to appear on the comment.

*Current Behavior*
Steps to reproduce:
# Attach the default resolution screen to a workflow step.
#* Add the "Attachment" field to the resolution screen.
# Transition the issue.
# The default resolution screen should appear. Add an attachment.

At the moment, the attachment is not automatically added as a comment as seen in [^image-2019-02-15-15-29-30-676.png]

*Suggested Behavior*
Make it so that after adding the attachment, it is included in the comment, as seen in  [^image-2019-02-15-15-30-27-461.png]

*Other notes*
The observation of current behavior also applies to Service Desk projects (adding an internal or external comment).
fields.summary: Automatically append attachment to comment when attaching via screens

https://confluence.atlassian.com/kb/proxying-atlassian-server-applications-with-microsoft-internet-information-services-iis-833931378.html

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

File viewer plugin used by Jira to preview PDF files cannot preview PDF files with certain embedded fonts. It expects the loca and glyf tables to decode the embedded fonts. At times some of the PDF files created by third party vendors do not provide these tables and expect the PDF reader to be able to decode them. The same file can be previewed successfully by acrobat PDF viewer and firefox or chrome which uses OpenType Sanitizer for decoding fonts.

The PDF which cannot be previewed had MicrosoftYaheiUI as the embedded font with 
Truetype (CID) and identity-H encoding. It errors out with 
{code}
Error: Required "loca" table is not found com.atlassian.jira.jira-fileviewer-plugin:fileviewer-pdf-worker.js:47:171
{code}

h3. Workaround
Download the file and preview it with acrobat reader or default browser
fields.summary: File viewer plugin used by Jira to preview PDF cannot preview PDF files with certain embedded fonts

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
 - Manual installation of Jira 8.0.0 Windows service using service.bat doesn't work, it appears that the batch script is broken

h3. Environment
 * Windows

h3. Steps to Reproduce

 # Perform a clean installation of Jira 8.0.0 without installing it as a service
 # Manually install the service using service.bat
{code:java}
service.bat install jira{code}

OR 

 # Perform an upgrade to Jira 8.0.0 without installing it as a service
 # Manually install the service using service.bat
{code:java}
service.bat install jira{code}

h3. Expected Results

Service successfully installed.
h3. Actual Results

Windows service failed to install.

The error {{8 was unexpected at this time.}} is thrown.
{code:java}
C:\Program Files\Atlassian\JIRATEST\bin>service.bat install jira
Neither the JAVA_HOME nor the JRE_HOME environment variable is defined
Service will use the bundled JRE.
Failing that, service will try to guess them from the registry.
Installing the service 'JIRASoftware140219193604' ...
Using CATALINA_HOME:    "C:\Program Files\Atlassian\JIRA"
Using CATALINA_BASE:    "C:\Program Files\Atlassian\JIRA"
Ignoring JAVA_HOME:        ""
Using JRE_HOME:         "C:\Program Files\Atlassian\JIRA\bin\\..\jre"
Using JVM:              "C:\Program Files\Atlassian\JIRA\bin\\..\jre\bin\server\jvm.dll"
8 was unexpected at this time.
{code}
h3. Workaround

We have tested the below workaround on Windows Server 2016:
 * Open a new Windows cmd as an *Administrator*
 * Please go the the JIRA installation Directory eg:
{code:java}
cd C:\Program Files\Atlassian\JIRA {code}

 * Set the following windows environment variable as below:
{code:java}
 set JRE_HOME=.\jre {code}
This is basically pointing to the *JRE_HOME* in this step, the path "*.\jre*" should be the path of the JRE and *shouldn't contain spaces*.
 You can also us an absoulute path like this:
{code:java}
set JRE_HOME=C:\Progra~1\Atlassian\JIRA\jre
{code}
The path in this case should use the 8 character form, the one without spaces.

 * Once the JRE_HOME Path is set and you are still in the installation directory: *C:\Program Files\Atlassian\JIRA*, run the service command as below:
{code:java}
 .\bin\service install jira {code}

This should allow the service to be installed.
fields.summary: Manual installation of Jira 8.0.0 Windows service doesn't work

fields.description:

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
When installing JIRA 8 as a Windows Service, the default memory allocation value is -Xms256m and -Xmx2048m. However, in the startup logs, we can see a warning message that indicates the following:
{quote}
The initial memory allocation pool (-Xms) is recommended to be at least 384m.
{quote}

h3. Environment
* Windows

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Download the JIRA 8 installer
# Install JIRA as a Service.
# Start the application and review the startup sequence logs.

h3. Expected Results
# The default memory allocation should be set to -xms 384MB instead of 256MB.
# No warning appear on the logs.

h3. Actual Results
# The default memory allocation is set to -xms 256MB.
# The following warning appears:
{code}
2019-02-14 17:44:13,653 JIRA-Bootstrap WARN      [c.a.jira.health.HealthChecks] JIRA runs in a Java virtual machine (JVM), and this JVM is allocated an amount of memory to enable JIRA to run. These amounts can be manually configured.
       - The initial memory allocation pool (-Xms) is recommended to be at least 384m.
{code}

h3. Workaround
* Update the memory parameters to have at least 384MB of xms as per [Increasing Jira application memory|https://confluence.atlassian.com/adminjiraserver/increasing-jira-application-memory-938847654.html]
fields.summary: Installing JIRA 8 as a Windows Service defaults -xms to 256MB instead of the recommended 384MB

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
Jira suggests installing Service Desk 8.0 EAP8 instead of the correct version of Service Desk associated with the version of Jira being used.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Go to Jira Administration > Applications > Versions & Licenses
 # Look in the bottom right corner of the screen.

h3. Expected Results
Jira suggests trying the version of Service Desk associated with Jira per [Jira Service Desk - Version History|https://marketplace.atlassian.com/apps/1213632/jira-service-desk/version-history]

h3. Actual Results
Jira suggest trying Service Desk 8.0 EAP8
 !image-2019-02-14-17-11-42-832.png|thumbnail! 
 !Jira7.6.4.png|thumbnail! 

h3. Notes
This seems to be a visual issue only as pressing the button actually install the correct version of Jira Service Desk.
This issue occurs with any Jira version: Jira will always suggest trying Service Desk 8.0 EAP8, regardless of the Jira version that is currently installed.

fields.description:
h3. Description
The variation between how the numeric value differs the decimal place between a comma and a dot depends on the Language Pack selected at the Default Language configuration at the System Administration page of Jira. However, there is an issue when using number that end with a whole number at the decimal units, Jira eats the 0 (zero).

*Example in English language*
User input: 7.90
After saving: 7.9

User input: 7.92
After saving: 7.92

*Example in Portuguese language*
User input: 104846,40
After saving: 104.846,4

User input: 104846,43
After saving: 104.846,43

As per [this article on Significant Zeroes|https://www.physics.uoguelph.ca/tutorials/sig_fig/SIG_dig.htm]:
{quote}Zeroes placed after other digits but behind a decimal point are significant; 7.90 has three significant digits.{quote}

From my perspective, Jira shouldn't be "eating" the decimal 0 (zero) on whole numbers and that cause issues to customers from other countries that use Languages where it is important to have the whole decimal number displayed.

h3. Workaround
There is no current known workaround to be applied on this situation. If you find one, please leave a comment with the steps to achieve it.
fields.summary: Keep the 0 unit in decimal place of Numeric field types with whole tens at the end

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

When browsing Jira, not all sub-menus are accessible using keyboard, and thus are not readable by the screen readers.
h3. Environment
 * Jira 7.6.11, 7.13.1, or some of the earlier versions
 * Any modern browser (tested on Edge, Firefox and Chrome)
 * NVDA 2018.4.1 (but will also be reproducible with older versions, as it's an issue with Jira's navigation, not with the screen reader)

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Head to the issue.
 # Press 'H' until you reach the Summary heading.
 # Using the 'K' button on the keyboard, head to the next link until you reach the 'More' button. Enter Focus Mode by pressing NVDA+Space. (NVDA is the insert button by default)
 # Press 'Enter', then navigate to the sub-menu using the keyboard.
 # You are unable to navigate the submenu properly using just the arrow keys - the furthest you can go is until the "Attach files" item.

h3. Expected Results

All menu items will be accessible and readable by the screen reader.
h3. Actual Results

Not all menu items are accessible using just the arrow keys.
h3. Workaround

One has to jump to the end of the virtual buffer to access the menu items after "Attach files".
Those items will be accessible by keyboard, *but will not be read properly*.
fields.summary: Some issue menu's sub-items are not accessible and are not readable when using screen readers

fields.description:
h3. Summary

JIRA Issue dates event types will not display in Team Calendars if JIRA user timezone is set to GMT format.
h3. Environment

This was tested with:
 * Confluence 6.7.2, 6.12
 * JIRA 7.8.0, 7.12
 * Team Calendar 6.0.25
 * JIRA iCalendar Plugin 1.4.7

h3. Problem

If JIRA is set to use a “GMT-X” user timezone format, then JIRA Issue dates event does not display in Team Calendars on Confluence.
h3. Expected Results

JIRA Issue dates should be rendered in Team Calendars with any timezone format.
h3. Actual Results

The JIRA event can only be seen if the user.timezone is set to America/Los_Angeles, for example.
If the timezone is set to GMT -X format, the following error is seen in Confluence application logs:
{code:java}
ERROR [http-nio-10.80.10.12-8090-exec-8] [confluence.extra.calendar3.DefaultCalendarManager] executeActionOnHierachy Error on sub calendar com.atlassian.confluence.extra.calendar3.calendarstore.generic.JiraIssueDatesSubCalendarDataStore$JiraIssueDatesSubCalendar@62ce03f7
– url: /plugins/servlet/team-calendars/caldav/4f2cc742-ef63-4981-aca2-ecc38fbb9510/ | traceId: 88863c8533e03f98 | userName: user1
java.lang.NullPointerException
at com.atlassian.confluence.extra.calendar3.calendarstore.CalendarDataStoreCachingDecorator.getEvents(CalendarDataStoreCachingDecorator.java:613)
at com.atlassian.confluence.extra.calendar3.calendarstore.DelegatingCalendarDataStore.getEvents(DelegatingCalendarDataStore.java:734)
at com.atlassian.confluence.extra.calendar3.DefaultCalendarManager.lambda$getEvents$3(DefaultCalendarManager.java:636)
at com.atlassian.confluence.extra.calendar3.DefaultCalendarManager.executeActionOnHierachy(DefaultCalendarManager.java:686)
at com.atlassian.confluence.extra.calendar3.DefaultCalendarManager.getEvents(DefaultCalendarManager.java:632)
at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method)
{code}
And the following error is seen in JIRA application logs:
{code:java}
2019-01-14 19:05:48,539 http-nio-8080-exec-10 ERROR cwhite 1145x659255x1 1jqvjj7 10.80.10.12,127.0.0.1 /rest/ical/1.0/ical/search/filter/events.ics [c.a.j.extra.icalfeed.IcalendarResource] Unable to export issues to iCalendar
java.lang.NullPointerException
at com.atlassian.jira.extra.icalfeed.IcalendarResource.toIcalendar(IcalendarResource.java:331)
at com.atlassian.jira.extra.icalfeed.IcalendarResource.search(IcalendarResource.java:305)
at com.atlassian.jira.extra.icalfeed.IcalendarResource.getIcalendarByJql(IcalendarResource.java:286)
at sun.reflect.GeneratedMethodAccessor5237.invoke(Unknown Source)
at sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:43)
at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:498)
... 19 filtered
at com.atlassian.plugins.rest.module.RestDelegatingServletFilter$JerseyOsgiServletContainer.doFilter(RestDelegatingServletFilter.java:154)
... 1 filtered
{code}
h3. Workaround

Set the following JVM argument in the setenv.sh file (for Linux) or setenv.bat file (for Windows) of JIRA:
{panel}
-Duser.timezone=America/Los_Angeles
{panel}
fields.summary: JIRA Issue dates event types will not display in Team Calendars if JIRA user timezone is set to GMT format

fields.description:
h3. Summary

The {{application.wadl}} file provided by the Jira REST API duplicates the API path in both the resource base and the resource path, leading to an invalid URL.

This also breaks integration with the [Atlassian REST API Browser|https://marketplace.atlassian.com/apps/1211542/atlassian-rest-api-browser] plugin making it provide wrong REST resource URLs.
h3. Steps to reproduce
 # Log in to a Jira instance running Jira 8.0 or above
 # Access <JIRA_URL>/rest/api/2/application.wadl (in case you are checking from the browser and you are seeing JSON instead of XML, right click and select "View page source")

h3. Expected result

{{<ns2:resource>}} elements don't contain "{{api/2/}}" prefix, as it used to be in previous Jira versions (Checked Jira 7.12.0)
 e.g.
{code:java}
    <ns2:resources base="https://localhost:8090/rest/api/2/">
        <ns2:resource path="permissionscheme">
{code}
h3. Actual result

{{<ns2:resource>}} elements contains "{{api/2/}}" prefix
 e.g.
{code:java}
    <ns2:resources base="https://localhost:8090/rest/api/2/">
        <ns2:resource path="api/2/permissionscheme">
{code}
h3. Notes

The duplicated "{{api/2/}}" prefix breaks integration with [Atlassian REST API Browser|https://marketplace.atlassian.com/apps/1211542/atlassian-rest-api-browser] plugin making it provide wrong REST resource URLs.
h3. Workaround

For applications that rely on the WADL and do not function correctly (such as the Atlassian REST API Browser) it might be possible to rewrite the URLs. The following workaround has been tested in Jira 8.2.1 with the most recent version of the Atlassian Rest API Browser:
 # Shut down Jira, and make a backup of {{$jira-install/conf/server.xml}}
 # Add the following to {{$jira-install/conf/server.xml}}, just before the closing {{</Host>}} tag:
{code:java}
<Valve className="org.apache.catalina.valves.rewrite.RewriteValve" />
{code}

 # Create a new file at {{$jira-install/conf/Catalina/localhost/rewrite.config}} with the following contents:
{code:java}
RewriteRule ^/rest/api/([0-9][.]?[0-9]?)/api/[0-9][.]?[0-9]?/(.*)$ /rest/api/$1/$2
{code}
(!) Note: The path to the rewrite config file will depend on your server.xml. The folder path will be created - so you can use whatever folders have been created under {{$jira-install/conf}}.
 (!) Note: If you're using a context path, make sure to include that in the {{rewrite.config}} file - both in the rule, and the rewrite section as well, before {{/rest}}

 # Restart Jira

While this workaround doesn't affect the incorrect display in the WADL file, it will ensure that any requests to the REST API will be redirected correctly to the same API; and allowing integrations using the WADL to function correctly (such as the REST API browser).
fields.summary: Jira duplicates REST resource root path in WADL

fields.description:
h3. Summary
JQL searches ignore custom fields contexts when sorting. The only value taken in consideration is the option sequence number in the database.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create two projects, called *ONE* and *TWO*.
# Create a custom field with type *Select List (multiple choices)* named *Country*.
# Add a context for each project (*ONE* and *TWO*) and add options to each context in the following way:
 !cf-contexts.png|thumbnail! 
# Create issues on both projects, randomly assigning values of *Country* to each issue. The script below might help:
{code:none|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#6A8EB3|bgColor=#F8F8F8}
#!/bin/bash
USERNAME="admin"
PASSWORD="admin"
BASE_URL="http://localhost:8080"
URL="$BASE_URL/rest/api/2/issue/"
KEY="TWO"
AMOUNT=25
for i in $(seq $AMOUNT)
do
  COUNTRY=$(shuf -n1 -e 'Malaysia' 'Indonesia' 'Hong Kong' 'China' 'Thailand')
  DATA="{ \"fields\": { \"project\": { \"key\": \"$KEY\" }, \"summary\": \"Task #$i\", \"description\": \"Task #$i \", \"customfield_10007\": [{ \"value\":\"$COUNTRY\" }], \"issuetype\": { \"name\": \"Task\" } } }"
  curl -u $USERNAME:$PASSWORD -X POST --data "$DATA" -H 'Content-Type: application/json' $URL
  echo
done
{code}
# Run the following JQL query:
{code:none|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#6A8EB3|bgColor=#F8F8F8}
issuetype = Task ORDER BY Country ASC
{code}

h3. Expected Results
All issues are sorted by their value of *Country*, in alphabetical order.

h3. Actual Results
Issues are displayed out of order in regard to to the field *Country*, like in the example below:
 !wrong-sorting-order.png|thumbnail! 

h3. Workaround
None
fields.summary: JQL searches ignore custom fields contexts when sorting

fields.description:
Currently, If you download the Jira Core package, and perform the installation, it will install it and both Software and Service Desk will not be shown to the user in an active way.

The same happens when you install Jira Software bundle (which is actually Jira Core+Jira Software), Service Desk will not be "visible" and most admins might not know that they can install it on top of their current installation by simply adding the app at Jira Administration > Applications > Versions & Licenses.

The suggestion is to include a Popup or notification in some way, either after installation of the first time an admin user logs in, where it is hinted that Service Desk/Software can be installed and tested for free without performing another installation, and maybe even adding a link to direct the customer to Versions & Licenses where they can see the "Try me" buttons for the application that is not yet installed.

fields.description:
Jira does not provide an API for rendering/querying the state of its internal gadgets. This could be useful for e.g. other products and plugin developers who would like to embed them within their apps. Currently, the only way to obtain info about these gadgets is to use Jira's internal API which hasn't been designed with this use case in mind. This may lead to issues such as https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-41311.

 
{panel:title=Previous bug description}
h5. Title: The Two Dimensional Filter Statistics Gadget REST api renders links using the request URL, rather than the configured base URL
h5. Steps to Reproduce
 # Setup JIRA behind a reverse proxy, with an alternative access port
 ** Assume that {{[http://localhost:8080/jira]}} is the unproxied URL
 ** Assume that {{[http://localhost/jira]}} is the proxied address
 ** The base URL is set to the unproxied URL until after the application link is created
 # Setup Confluence
 # Create an application link to {{localhost:8080/jira}}
 # Change JIRA's base URL to the proxied address
 # In the application link configuration, change JIRA's display URL to the proxied address
 ** Communication will go from Confluence to JIRA over the unproxied port, but user facing links will use the display URL for hyperlinks.
 # Insert a Two Dimensional Macro Chart Macro in Confluence

h5. Expected Results

The links in the chart link to the proxied address
h5. Actual Results

The links in the chart use the application URL instead. If that port is not accessible to users, this may result in links failing, or if the DNS does not resolve.
h5. Cause

This bug is the result of a problem in Jira's gadget REST api ([http://hostname:1990/rest/gadget/1.0/twodimensionalfilterstats/generate?filterId=jql-]), which incorrectly uses the request url as the base for links in the results, rather than Jira's configured baseUrl.

This means that any applicationLink requests made to this REST api would have the results rendered using the applicationLink's baseUrl, rather than the configured displayUrl.

The two dimensional charts macro can't fix this problem. Instead, this bug has to be fixed inside Jira's gadget REST api. Either make the links in the twodimentionalfilterstats rest api a relative link, or use the configured baseUrl as the base for the (absolute) links.
{panel}
fields.summary: Jira should provide an API for querying data about its gadgets

h3. Problem Definition
From the documentation below, we are instructed to copy some folder from Local Home to Shared Home:
- https://confluence.atlassian.com/adminjiraserver/installing-jira-data-center-938846870.html

The mentioned folder are:
- data
- plugins
- logos
- import
- export
- caches

But, there is no instruction whether it is safe to remove the mentioned folders from Local Home after it is copied to Shared Home.

While we can keep the caches folder as it is crucial for the Node index, there is no information regarding this and for the other folder as well.

fields.description:
h3. Summary
The _upgrade.xml_ file is not being updated and as a result Jira triggers an upgrade ({{c.a.jira.upgrade.UpgradeScheduler}}) on each restart due to build number difference

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Install Jira 7.3.x 
# Restart the instance 
# Note the build number in the logs
{code}
    ****************
    JIRA starting...
    ****************
    
2019-02-11 09:16:24,442 localhost-startStop-1 INFO      [c.a.jira.startup.JiraStartupLogger] 
    
    ___ Environment _____________________________
    
         JIRA Build                                    : 7.3.8#73019-sha1:94e8771b8094eef96c119ec22b8e8868d286fa88
{code}
{code}
    ___ Upgrade History ________________________
    
         7.3.8#73011
              Time Performed                                : 2017-09-21 07:55:49.151
{code}
# Compare this with the last line in {{$Jira_Installation_Directory/atlassian-jira/WEB-INF/classes/upgrade.xml}}
{code}
    <upgrade build="73011">
        <class>com.atlassian.jira.upgrade.tasks.UpgradeTask_Build73011</class>
    </upgrade>
{code}
(i) Build number 73011 refers to Jira 7.3.0 as per [Jira Build and Version Numbers Reference|https://confluence.atlassian.com/jirakb/jira-build-and-version-numbers-reference-347341143.html]

h3. Expected Results
Jira build number matches across the logs and _upgrade.xml_ file 

h3. Actual Results
Jira build number did not match across the logs and _upgrade.xml_ file. This subsequently triggers the {{UpgradeScheduler}} on each application restart

 
h3. Notes
* This is only observed in Jira version 7.3 and above
* There are no negative impact from the {{UpgradeScheduler}}
fields.summary: upgrade.xml file not updated in newer releases and triggers upgrade on every restart

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Presently, Jira doesn't distinguish between authentication and authorization failure in terms of incrementing the login failure count. In the latter case, this could lead to unexpected lockouts of LDAP accounts for users who aren't aware they don't have access to Jira, especially for environments with restrictive lockout policies. 

In addition, locking accounts due to authorization failures can lead to administrative overhead in that these accounts will likely need to be manually unlocked.

h3. Suggested Solution
Don't increment the failed login count for authorization failures, only authentication failures. 

h3. Notes
This _might_ have security implications, as changing authentication vs authorization behavior may lead bad actors to distinguish valid vs invalid usernames.
fields.summary: As an administrator, I don't want login failure counts to be incremented in an authorization failure scenario

fields.description:
Whenever an email contains an illegal character or there is something wrong with the email formatting, Jira will throw an error like the following: Could not parse message recipients.
javax.mail.internet.AddressException: Domain contains illegal character in string ``'_email address_''' and will simply reject the email.

The suggestion is to improve the handling for these email by using a default reporter to process the email and add a message indicating there was a problem, adding the available information so the agent can have a better idea of what happened and who to reach out to.

Workaround: use a third party add-on like [Jira Enterprise Mail Handler|https://marketplace.atlassian.com/apps/4832/enterprise-email-handler-for-jira-jemh?hosting=server&tab=overview] or [Email this issue|https://marketplace.atlassian.com/apps/4977/email-this-issue?hosting=server&tab=overview] which seem to have options to deal with these scenarios.
fields.summary: Improve handling of emails with illegal characters

fields.description:
This is a regression of JRASERVER-59495

h3.Summary
The "Log Work" functionality is using the JIRA System "Default user time zone" to set the "Date Started".
It should be using the "User Time zone" set in the Profile section

h3.Steps to Reproduce
Go to an issue, click on "Log Work" and check the Time in "Date Started"
Change your user timezone by going to your Profile
Refresh the issue
Click on "Log Work" and check the "Date Started" field again
Expected Results
The Time defaults to the timezone recently set in the profile

h3.Actual Results
The Time remains the same as before because it still uses the JIRA "Default user time zone"

h3.Notes
Changing the JIRA "Default user time zone" under "General Configuration" will change the time shown by default by the "Log Work", confirming the link between them.
All other dates in the issues, such as Created, Updated, Comment times, change accordingly to the user timezone.

(i) This behavior is reproducible in 7.13.5, 8.2.1, and 8.2.4 by adding the *Log Work* field to a new custom screen (in that case the default Log Work field displays the user's preferred time zone -- but the custom screen displays incorrectly.

h3. Workaround
Currently there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available
fields.summary: Regression: Log Work uses Default user timezone instead of User's timezone

fields.description:

What would be required is to export a single "Latest Sprint" field that contains only the latest sprint for any record, or blank if it has never been allocated to a sprint.
fields.summary: Export only single Sprint field

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition:

Currently, to access the workflow information like transition screens, properties, triggers, conditions, post functions, etc, the user first needs to click on Edit button in the diagram mode and then access all this information. It is not possible to see this information without going into Edit mode for a workflow.

Some user wants to access this information without clicking the Edit button.


h3. Suggested Solution:

Allow User to view and access (in read-only) this information related to a workflow without clicking on Edit button.


h3. Why this is important:

Clicking on the Edit button is an additional step that the user has to perform every time s/he needs to access the workflow related information and it becomes tedious for the user.


h3. Workaround:

The user can use text mode instead of diagram mode and click on the transition step to access the information such as properties, triggers, conditions, post functions, etc.
fields.summary: Allow User to view and access (in read-only) Workflow related information without clicking on Edit button in the Diagram mode.

fields.description:
h3.Summary
Jira displays the wrong Error message in the scenario where the user has 'Browse Project' permission but not 'Create Issue' permission and the user tries to move the issue. The current error thrown by the system is:
{quote}
"You're not allowed to browse projects.
To change your permissions, please contact your Jira administrators."
{quote}
This error seems to be wrong since create permission is missing and not the browse permission.

h3.Environment
JIRA Software 7.13.0

h3.Expected Results
The error displayed should be "You're not allowed to create issues".


h3.Actual Results
The current error thrown by the system is:
{quote}
"You're not allowed to browse projects.
To change your permissions, please contact your Jira administrators."
{quote}

h3.Workaround
Using the developers tool user can identify the div/table where this message is getting populated. Based on that administrator can write a Javascript and insert it to Announcement Banner to make JIRA display a different message when the warning is triggered.
fields.summary: Wrong permission error message gets displayed to user.

fields.description:
h3. *+Summary+*

For the [documentation|https://confluence.atlassian.com/adminjiraserver0711/migrating-jira-applications-to-another-server-955167864.html], the guide is not specific to the types of server migration.

Instead of generalizing everything to be installed using Archive file, there should be guide for users that are using the Installer to migrate. Assuming the migration is for the same version of Jira in a new server.

+*Situation 1 : User would like to migrate Jira to another server using the same database.*+
# Install Jira in the new server.
 # Stop Jira in the old server.
# Copy the <home directory> of the old instance to the new server home directory path without changing anything in the {{dbconfig.xml}}.
# Remove dbconfig.xml from old/source JIRA server so it doesn't get accidentally connected to the db again
# Start up Jira in new server.

+*Situation 2 : User would like to migrate Jira using the Installer instead of Archive*+

In the documentation, we should emphasize that if a user is using an installer, they should skip step 3. 

Also, in the documentation : 
{quote}Download the {{zip}} or {{tar.gz}} archive – [Jira Core|https://www.atlassian.com/software/jira/core/download] or [Jira Software|https://www.atlassian.com/software/jira/download].
{quote}
It should be instead : 
{quote}Download the installer, {{zip}} or {{tar.gz}} archive – [Jira Core|https://www.atlassian.com/software/jira/core/download], [Jira Service Desk |https://www.atlassian.com/software/jira/service-desk/download] or [Jira Software|https://www.atlassian.com/software/jira/download]. 
{quote}
fields.summary: Migration Documentation is not specific to user's migration use case

fields.description:
h3. Summary

Jira could ship with Java application that would replace all of shell starting/configuration scripts. Running the application would create a configured Tomcat instance with Jira webapp.

This would have following adventages:
* Jira wouldn't rely on shell startup scripts, making it more OS agnostic - fixing e.g. JRASERVER-68811
* Jira could manage default vs custom configuration (JRASERVER-68882) for:
** Tomcat
** JVM/GC
** Logging
* Mentioned above configurations could be stored in jirahome/database making upgrade process less complicated, as the configuration wouldn't need to be reapplied.
* Atlassian SDK could run Jira directly from Java without need of it's own Tomcat

fields.description:
h3. Summary
Jira fails to start on Solaris when executing the startup manually. This also happens when upgrading instance manually.

h3. Environment
* JIRA 7.13.1 running on Solaris.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Run the {{start-jira.sh}} or else {{check-java.sh}} and try to start Jira.

h3. Expected Results
Jira starts without issue.
h3. Actual Results
There's a grep -E on the {{check-java.sh}} that is avoiding Jira to check what the Java version is. Solaris cannot use the -E option on grep as the syntax for recursively grep is different on Solaris.

{code}
#!/bin/sh

_EXPECTED_JAVA_VERSION="8"

#

    check for correct java version by parsing out put of java -version
    we expect first line to be in format '(java|openjdk) version "1.8.0_40"' and assert that minor version number will be 8 or higher
    #

"$_RUNJAVA" -version 2>&1 | grep -E "(java|openjdk) version" | (
IFS=. read ignore1 version ignore2
if [ ! ${version:-0} -ge "$_EXPECTED_JAVA_VERSION" ]
then
echo "*************************************************************************************************************************************"
echo "********** Wrong JVM version! You are running with "$ignore1"."$version"."$ignore2" but JIRA requires at least 1.8 to run. **********"
echo "*************************************************************************************************************************************"
exit 1
fi
)
if [ $? -ne 0 ] ; then
exit 1
fi
{code}

{code}
Server startup logs are located in /app/jira/logs/catalina.out
Using CATALINA_BASE: /app/jira
Using CATALINA_HOME: /app/jira
Using CATALINA_TMPDIR: /app/jira/temp
Using JRE_HOME: /usr
Using CLASSPATH: /app/jira/bin/bootstrap.jar:/app/jira/bin/tomcat-juli.jar
Using CATALINA_PID: /app/jira/work/catalina.pid
grep: illegal option -- E
Usage: grep [-c|-l|-q] -bhinsvw pattern file . . .
*************************************************************************************************************************************
********** Wrong JVM version! You are running with .. but JIRA requires at least 1.8 to run. **********
*************************************************************************************************************************************
{code}

h3. Workaround
Edit the {{check-java.sh}} file and remove the -E option off the grep to be able to start Jira.
fields.summary: Jira fails to start on Solaris when executing the startup manually.

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
{{EagerLoadingOfBizCustomFieldPersister}} caches all Custom Field values related to specific Issue from {{customfieldvalue}} table in _request-scope_ cache.

This caching was introduced as a performance optimisation to speed up issue indexing.
 Probably it also helps in ViewIssue, issue-nav's table view and sorting by custom field through a database.

However, currently this cache can grow indefinitely and this can cause high memory pressure.

h3. Suggested Solution
Introduce some limits to the cache size, I.e. 1/10/100 issues only

h3. Notes
In the following example, we have cached values for 62k issues. (each having ~50 cf values)
!cf-request-cache.png|width=362,height=302,thumbnail!

h3. Notes on fix
Copy from [focusedCommentId=1972882|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-66555?focusedCommentId=1972882&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:comment-tabpanel#comment-1972882]

h4. Background
In Jira many custom field values are read from DB. These values are often read in a loop, one by one. To minimise the number of DB calls, when one custom field value is read, {{EagerLoadingOfBizCustomFieldPersister}} reads and caches all of the values for the given issue. This is a request-scoped cache, so as soon as one Jira page is displayed, it's binned.

h4. Problem
In some cases the request scope lasts for long time. This is the case for example for CSV export, where all issues are exported in one go. The cache keeps on accumulating custom field values for longer than needed - as soon as an issue has been written out, it won't be accessed any more. There's no point in keeping it in memory. Yet, until this fix, we did that.

Another example (which is not really a real web request) is when a batch of issues is indexed. As soon as one issue has been indexed, we don't need to keep it in the memory. For this we had a workaround of cleaning the cache manually, which is redundant now.

h4. Fix summary
*We changed the custom field cache from unbounded to size 10 (LRU)*. In most cases size 1 would be enough, but in some scenarios, e.g. reading a subtask and its parent, a slightly bigger cache will be beneficial. 

h4. Fix performance
I tested CSV export of 100K issues, each having 10 custom field values. Before the fix the request cache would have ~1945MB at the end of the export, now it has ~57MB.

Running our [JPT|https://bitbucket.org/atlassian/jira-performance-tests] showed no performance regression. Indexing speed wasn't impacted either.
fields.summary: Custom Field Value cache can grow indefinitely

fields.description:
2 improvements to make in this documentation: https://confluence.atlassian.com/adminjiraserver073/creating-issues-and-comments-from-email-861253784.html

*Improvement 1*

I would be great if we could improve the definition of the *Default Reporter* setting for the mail handler of type *Create a new issue or add a comment to an existing issue*.

This setting is described as follows, which is correct:
{quote}
Specify the username of a default reporter, which will be used if the email address in the From: field of any received messages does not match the address associated with that of an existing JIRA user
{quote}

However, it might be helpful to add something like this:
{quote}
If the mail handler is able to match an existing JIRA user with the email address of the From: field, and if this user does not have the permission to create issues within the project or does not have application access or is inactive, the issue creation will fail with either error "Reporter (XXXX) does not have permission to create an issue. Message rejected." OR "Cannot create issue due to invalid license: [Sorry, you can't create any issues right now, as you need to have access to a Jira application to be able to create issues".
In this case, the mail handler won't try to create the issue using the default reporter as the reporter to compensate for the error.
{quote}

This information will help our customers understand/tackle the situation described in the bug https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-36497 faster.

*Improvement 2*

If multiple users in JIRA are using the same email address, but some of them are inactive, there is a chance that JIRA will try to match the email address of the From: field when trying to create the issue by email, and will fail with either error "Reporter (XXXX) does not have permission to create an issue. Message rejected." OR "Cannot create issue due to invalid license: [Sorry, you can't create any issues right now, as you need to have access to a Jira application to be able to create issues".

It might be good to mention it somewhere in the documentation, maybe as a warning with a link to this KB article https://confluence.atlassian.com/jirakb/jira-mail-handler-cannot-create-issue-from-some-users-email-827097833.html, so that our customers can tackle this scenario more easily when they are facing the bug https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-33116
fields.summary: Improving documentation about 'Creating Issues and Comments from Email'

fields.description:
h3. Summary
If the account used to authenticate with Github has access to too many repos, JIRA will not be able to finish retrieving all the repos for the import if it hits API Rate Limit Exceeded.

h3. Steps to reproduce
# Own a Github account that has access to a huge amount of repos (as in the case of Enterprise customers).
# Use Github Importer from External System Import to import Github issues into JIRA
# Authenticate using the account in #1

h3. Expected behavior
JIRA is able to retrieve the repo list for the import in all cases

h3. Actual behavior
JIRA may fail with this error:
{code}
2019-02-01 09:30:01,560 ajp-nio-8009-exec-790 ERROR username 569x23327786x6 3t9v8u 10.20.30.40 /secure/admin/GithubProjectMappingPage!default.jspa [c.atlassian.velocity.DefaultVelocityManager] MethodInvocationException occurred getting message body from Velocity: java.lang.RuntimeException: org.eclipse.egit.github.core.client.RequestException: API rate limit exceeded for user ID 12345. (403)
java.lang.RuntimeException: org.eclipse.egit.github.core.client.RequestException: API rate limit exceeded for user ID 12345. (403)
{code}

h3. Suggestion
The importer should have an option to specify the repos to import from, rather than have JIRA scan through all the repos

h3. Workaround
Temporarily transfer the ownership of the to-be-imported repos to a different account and use that account for the import
fields.summary: Github Importer may Fail with API Rate Limit Exceeded

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

When clicking one of the existing filter suggested by filter picker on IE 11 a Javascript error is thrown and logged to dev console.
h3. Environment
* IE 11

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Go to a dashboard
 # Add a gadget which incorporates a filter picker (e.g. Two Dimensional Filter Statistics)
 # Advance to gadget's configuration
 # Start typing an existing filter's name in the filter picker
 # Select one of the displayed suggestions

h3. Expected Results

Clicking a suggested filter name sets it as the configured filter.
h3. Actual Results

Clicking a suggested filter name does set is as the configured filter but there's also this exception thrown in console
{noformat}
Object doesn't support property or method 'includes'{noformat}
This is because IE 11 does not support 'includes' method. Luckily, the 'includes' method is used here when attempting to send an analytics event (if the analytics events are enabled on the instance) about using the filter picker. This means that the error does not impact the feature or dashboard in any way but just prevents this particular event (selecting a suggestion in filter picker) from being sent.
h3. Workaround

Currently there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available
fields.summary: Using filter picker in gadgets logs JS error 'Object doesn't support property or method includes' in IE 11

fields.description:
The REST API documentation (e.g. https://docs.atlassian.com/software/jira/docs/api/REST/7.12.0/#api/2/project/)  uses the terms user_key and username interchangeably. This leads to confusion because both values exist in the database schema and one value over the other fails.


If the endpoints can't be changed to accept username (instead of userkey) then I'd also suggest careful use of the relevant term in each endpoint's description and a description of the difference earlier in the documentation.

An explanatory sentence of this bug (JRASERVER-68189) on the REST documentation would be really useful or a more specific error message when the incorrect value is used.
fields.summary: Update REST API documentation to differentiate between username vs user_key

fields.description:
Ladies and Gentlemen,

in [https://confluence.atlassian.com/servicedeskserver/managing-the-email-channel-939926306.html] you describe that mails with attachments larger than 25MBytes will not be pulled.

We have run into the situation and are unhappy with the fact that no proper reaction is set in this case. The mail is left there unprocessed and neither the sender nor the service desk agent is informed that it was not processed.

I'd like to see a mail returned to the sender telling him that his email was rejected due to attachment size > 25MByte. Knowing his the sender can react and reduce the attachments and send it again and can be sure the service desk agent will receive the information. 

The other way around the service desk agent could be informed that there was a mail with attachments stripped due to too many data. Maybe together with a way how to retrieve the data via a different channel.

Thanks

 

Juergen
fields.summary: Service Desk Email Channel: show some reaction in case a mail larger than 25MByte is received

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
When using the "Import from CSV" tool, the *Original Estimate* field as per Atlassian documentation is supposed to informed in seconds, but it is divided by 60 two times if you have the "default unit" of Jira's time tracking configured to *minutes*, resulting in a wrong estimate.

h3. Environment
This was reproduced on the latest version Jira 7.12.1 and 7.13.1.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# When importing an issue from CSV, have the Original Estimate field in seconds, for example, * 28800* seconds.
# Have the "default unit" of your Jira Time Tracking configuration as *minutes*
# Use the *Import from CSV* tool and import the issue.

h3. Expected Results
The estimate of the issue will be 480 minutes, or 8 hours as expected.

h3. Actual Results
The estimate will be 8 minutes, instead of 8 hours as expected.
 !image.png|thumbnail! 

h3. Workaround
Set the "default units" of the Jira Time Tracking to *hours* instead of *minutes*.
fields.summary: "Original Estimate" field is divided by 60 twice when using the "Import from CSV" tool

h3. Summary
On the top menu dropdown lists, when you hover the mouse and highlight the menu option, the text doesn't change color(the color set in look and feel) and becomes hard to read the text.

h3. Environment

* Different browsers

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# On the top menu click in one of the options(e.g. Projects).
# Hover the mouse over one of the options (e.g current project).

h3. Expected Results
The background color of the options changes as well as the color of the text to highlight the option.

h3. Actual Results
Only the background gets highlighted and the text color stays the same making the text hard to read.
 
h3. Notes
The behavior started after an upgrade.

h3.Workaround
Change the "Menu Item Highlight Text Color" option in the Look and Feel to a different color and then change it back.

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

Jira Allows a project key pattern to be customized, this includes allowing special characters such as _, *,^, etc. However, this may break some functionality and throws a 404 errors
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Configure Jira project key pattern to allow special characters.
 # Create a project with a special character such as _ or ^ in the project key
 # Create an issue in the project

*Scenario 1*
 For a project that has a '_' in the project key:
 # Open an issue in a new tab.
 # Delete the issue
 # This shows a 404 error, despite the issue is successfully deleted

*Scenario 2*
 For a project that has a '^' in the project key:
 # Open the project in the issue navigator
 # Try to switch the filer to anther from the 'Switch Filter" menu
 # This shows a 404 and the filter does not work.

h3. Expected Results

If a project key pattern is allowed, it should not cause any error.
h3. Actual Results

a 404 error is thrown which may affect some functionality such as the below:

"The value 'undefined' does not exist for the field 'project'"

!value_undefined.PNG|width=200,height=150!

A HAR file shows the following POST Request:
{code:java}
jql=project+%3D+%22undefined%22+AND+resolution+%3D+Unresolved+ORDER+BY+priority+DESC%2C+updated+DESC
&columnConfig=explicit&layoutKey=split-view&startIndex=0
{code}
h3. Workaround

For Scenario 1, delete the issue from the issue navigator in the list or details view instead of opening it in a new tab. 
 For Scenario 2, a JQL search may be used.
fields.summary: Project keys with special characters causes 404 errors

Adding any string at the end of a plain issue URL causes communication breakdown when adding a comment.

fields.description:
h3. Problem

Due dates may differ between the issue view and the activity stream when Jira timezone and user timezones are different.

As an example, if the server is set with a GMT+0 timezone and an issue is set with a due date of 28 February, a user with a GMT-8 timezone will see the due date as 27 February in the general or user-specific activity streams.

Because due date is a *date* field, rather than a *date/time* field, the due date will technically be 00:00:01 am on the 28th, which would be 16:00:01 pm GMT-8 on the 27th, hence the disparity.

 
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Configure Jira with a GMT+0 timezone
 # Add a user, set the user's timezone to GMT+0
 # Add a second user, set the user's timezone to GMT-8
 # Create a project and issue, assign a due date to that issue
 # Login and view the issue as the first user, then the second user to see the due date disparity. The second user should see that the due date is the prior day, the first user should see the the due date as the expected day. In both cases the issue view will exhibit the expected due date.

h3. One Suggested Solution

Change due date to be a date/time field and also display the timezone. This will help users to better understand why the dates are different and as a nice bonus allow to set a specific due time.
h3. Workaround

None at this time.
fields.summary: Issue view and activity show inconsistent due dates, leading to user confusion
